# International Alliances and Partnerships Enhancing AI Capabilities

## Overview of Multilateral AI Collaborations

Global efforts to enhance artificial intelligence (AI) capabilities are increasingly anchored in multilateral alliances that promote responsible innovation, ethical governance, and coordinated policy frameworks among nations. These partnerships play a vital role in ensuring that AI development aligns with shared democratic values and inclusive economic growth. Leading initiatives among G-7, OECD, and G-20 countries have established mechanisms for technical collaboration, data sharing, and standard-setting aimed at the trustworthy use and advancement of AI technologies[1][2].

## The Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence (GPAI)

The Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence (GPAI) stands out as the foremost multilateral alliance explicitly dedicated to advancing global AI cooperation. Launched in June 2020 and hosted by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), GPAI emerged from a proposal made at the 2018 G-7 Summit. It convenes experts across government, academia, industry, and civil society from 29 founding and partner countries, including Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom, the United States, and the European Union[1][2].

GPAI’s mission centers on fostering responsible AI development through practical projects and policy recommendations that address ethical, innovation, and governance challenges. Working groups within GPAI explore domains such as data governance, future of work, innovation and commercialization, and responsible AI. The partnership relies heavily on collaboration with the OECD, which provides secretariat support and research capacity, establishing a normative foundation for international AI policy coordination[2].

## Role of the G-7 in AI Cooperation

The G-7 countries serve as leading advocates of coordinated AI policy among advanced economies. Their collaboration has been instrumental in launching GPAI and ensuring consistency across national AI strategies. The United States, for example, maintains bilateral AI cooperation frameworks—such as those with the United Kingdom—and participates actively in multistakeholder forums like the G-7 Science and Technology Ministerial Meeting and the OECD’s work on AI principles. These engagements emphasize transparency, trustworthiness, and global research partnerships as pillars of international AI engagement[1].

Through these coordinated efforts, the G-7 has sought to align policy approaches, avoid regulatory fragmentation, and promote cross-border data flows that underpin AI innovation. This structure of collaboration also reflects the strategic effort of these nations to shape international norms for trustworthy AI systems that support open, data-driven economies[1].

## G-20 and Broader International Cooperation

The Group of Twenty (G-20), encompassing major AI powers such as China and Russia, also integrates AI into its agenda as part of broader discussions on digital transformation and economic inclusion. The G-20 adopted AI principles largely derived from the OECD’s recommendations, promoting a human-centered approach to AI and encouraging trusted data flows across borders[1]. However, the diverse membership of the G-20 often limits consensus on unified approaches to AI governance. Consequently, while the G-20 provides a valuable platform for discussion and alignment on high-level principles, it lacks the more targeted focus and policy coordination found in G-7 or OECD-driven initiatives[1].

## OECD’s Role in Global AI Governance

The OECD plays a pivotal role in shaping global AI policy frameworks and coordinating research among its 37 member states. It hosts GPAI and facilitates policy exchanges through the OECD AI Policy Observatory, which monitors AI developments worldwide. The OECD’s work emphasizes a multistakeholder approach that integrates technical, ethical, and economic dimensions of AI, providing governments with data and policy analysis to adapt to the increasingly complex AI landscape[1][2].

Importantly, the OECD’s AI principles—endorsed by numerous countries including G-20 members—establish key guidelines for human-centered, trustworthy, and accountable AI. These principles underpin many national AI strategies and serve as a benchmark for evaluating international collaborations and policy coherence among states[2].

## Regional and Sector-Specific Partnerships

Beyond the major multilateral organizations, countries in various regions have created their own frameworks to address local priorities in AI governance and capability building. The African Union (AU), for example, is actively developing AI frameworks that emphasize context-appropriate governance policies, focusing on equitable development and regulatory alignment suited to local needs[3]. Similarly, countries across Latin America, Southeast Asia, and Africa are engaging in joint efforts to promote ethical AI use and capacity building through initiatives that foster local datasets, computational infrastructure, and context-specific AI applications[3].

For emerging economies, partnerships with leading AI nations often include support for technical infrastructure and interoperability. The U.S. strategy, for instance, involves fostering AI ecosystems in developing regions to diversify global AI networks and reduce dependency on a single dominant infrastructure provider, counterbalancing China’s growing influence in the field[3].

## Cross-Sector Collaboration in Healthcare AI

AI collaboration extends deeply into sectoral applications, with healthcare being a prominent focus area. International partnerships in healthcare AI link academic, governmental, and private-sector organizations to develop contextually responsive technologies and build local capacity. Such cooperation often involves sharing medical datasets, conducting joint research, transferring technology, and co-developing AI tools designed to tackle regional health challenges. These projects particularly aim to bridge gaps between high-income and lower-income countries, contributing to equitable AI advancement through shared knowledge and responsible deployment practices[4].

## Summary of Key International Frameworks and Activities

Collectively, these initiatives define the major frameworks for international cooperation on AI development:

- **Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence (GPAI):** A key OECD-hosted, multistakeholder platform uniting over two dozen countries to operationalize responsible AI innovation and policy cooperation[1][2].  
- **G-7 and G-20 Forums:** Platforms for high-level discussion and policymaking on AI principles, promoting trustworthy, human-centered AI while varying in scope and coherence[1].  
- **OECD Frameworks:** Central to AI policy research and coordination, with principles widely adopted by advanced and emerging economies alike[1][2].  
- **Regional Initiatives and Sectoral Collaborations:** Including African Union frameworks and healthcare-focused AI partnerships that promote equitable AI capacity building and context-adapted governance[3][4].

These diverse alliances reflect the evolving global architecture of AI collaboration—one that combines multilateral policymaking, regional empowerment, and sectoral innovation to shape the future of responsible AI development worldwide.
node_8.report:
# The Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence: Coordinating Global Efforts for Responsible AI Governance

## Introduction to GPAI and Its Founding Purpose

The Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence (GPAI) stands as the first major international multilateral alliance explicitly dedicated to advancing AI in a manner that is both responsible and beneficial to humanity. Launched in June 2020, GPAI was first proposed during the 2018 G-7 Summit and has since evolved into a central multilateral initiative in the global AI landscape. Hosted by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), GPAI operates through a coalition of 29 member countries, including founding members such as Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom, the United States, and the European Union[1][2].  

GPAI brings together experts from governments, academia, civil society, and industry to collaboratively address the ethical, legal, social, and technical challenges posed by the rapid evolution of AI technologies. Its primary goal is to promote trustworthy and human-centered AI innovation while supporting economic growth and social inclusion through responsible AI deployment[1].

## Relationship with the OECD and G-7 Nations

The G-7 countries have played a decisive role in establishing and supporting GPAI, viewing it as a mechanism to align their national AI strategies and policies toward shared democratic and ethical principles. As the institutional host of GPAI, the OECD provides the partnership with its secretariat function and offers technical expertise, research support, and governance guidance. The OECD’s policy infrastructure ensures consistency between GPAI’s operational activities and the OECD’s broader AI Principles adopted by its member states and later endorsed by the G-20[1][2].  

The close connection between the G-7 and the OECD in managing GPAI underscores the alignment among advanced economies in steering AI toward trustworthy innovation. G-7 nations continue to coordinate AI-related policy through GPAI, maintaining a strong multistakeholder approach that emphasizes transparency, fairness, and accountability in AI systems[1].

## GPAI’s Structure, Working Groups, and Key Initiatives

GPAI functions through several working groups, each devoted to a critical area of AI governance and innovation. These groups engage in evidence-based policy creation, best practice sharing, and project-based collaboration that address pressing AI challenges such as data governance, future of work, and responsible AI research. The partnership mobilizes diverse international expertise to transform ethical AI principles into implementable, context-aware solutions that reflect both technical feasibility and societal values[2].  

By bridging academic research, public policy, and industrial innovation, GPAI demonstrates practical multilateral action on AI governance. Its interdisciplinary projects have produced tools, reports, and frameworks guiding national and international policymaking, reinforcing the partnership’s credibility as a global leader in responsible and cooperative AI development[1][2].

## Integration within Broader Multilateral Frameworks

GPAI’s work complements broader multilateral initiatives, particularly those of the OECD, G-7, and G-20. The OECD’s AI Principles, the first intergovernmental standard for AI governance, serve as a foundation for GPAI’s mission to ensure that AI remains human-centered and trustworthy. The G-20 adopted these principles, extending their influence beyond OECD members to include other global economies such as China and Russia[1].  

While G-20 forums contribute to a global dialogue on AI, their broader membership often results in less unified policy action compared to the G-7 and OECD. Within this context, GPAI offers a more focused platform for coordination among like-minded nations committed to ethical standards and transparent AI ecosystems[1][2].

## Regional and Sectoral Partnerships Complementing GPAI

In addition to the global framework provided by GPAI, regional and sector-specific initiatives play vital roles in extending responsible AI principles to diverse contexts. For instance, the African Union has launched efforts to develop an AI governance policy aligned with local needs and socioeconomic goals. Similarly, countries across Latin America and Southeast Asia engage in regional collaborations addressing capacity building, ethical AI education, and responsible data governance to ensure inclusivity in the global AI landscape[3].  

In the healthcare domain, cross-regional collaborations exemplify how AI can advance sustainable development goals. Partnerships between research institutions from high-income and low-income countries support the co-development of AI tools guided by local contexts, integrating data sharing, technology transfer, and workforce training to ensure equitable AI benefits[4]. These initiatives complement GPAI’s global agenda by emphasizing contextual adaptation, inclusivity, and technical cooperation across varying levels of economic development.

## Impact and Direction of Global AI Cooperation

The Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence has emerged as a significant mechanism for aligning AI innovation with democratic values and human rights. Through its coordination with the OECD, its foundation in the G-7’s strategic vision, and its engagement with regional and sectoral partners, GPAI facilitates a comprehensive, collaborative approach to AI governance. It represents not only a policy forum but a practical framework for operationalizing ethical principles into AI practice across nations.  

Together, GPAI and its allied initiatives continue to shape a multilateral ecosystem where international cooperation ensures that AI technologies are developed and deployed responsibly, inclusively, and transparently—anchoring global progress in AI within a shared commitment to humanity and trustworthiness[1][2][3][4].

excerpts:
U.S. AI policy also recognizes the importance of international cooperation on AI: The American AI Initiative recognizes partnerships with U.S. allies and partners represent a key “source of strategic competitive advantage,” and identifies the need to “engage internationally to promote a global environment that supports American AI research and innovation and opens markets for American AI industries.” The identified goals of engagement include supporting the uptake of trustworthy AI innovation and promoting trust in and adoption of AI technologies for economic growth and global security.
Ongoing U.S. efforts to foster international cooperation in AI include bilateral cooperation agreements such as the U.S.-U.K. Cooperation in Artificial Intelligence Research and Development, hosting and engaging in international and multistakeholder initiatives such as the G-7 Science and Technology Ministerial Meeting that launched the Global Partnership on AI, and participation in common and formalized AI principles for the innovative and trustworthy development and application of AI such as the OECD Principles on AI discussed below.
### The European Union approach to AI
The European Commission launched development of its AI strategy in 2017, tasking a High-Level Expert Group on AI to establish guidelines for the trustworthy and ethical use of AI in the EU and later releasing an assessment of Europe’s competitive position in AI.

The G-7 (Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the U.K., the U.S., with the EU participating) has been particularly focused on AI. It initiated the Global Partnership for AI (GPAI), promoted by Canada during its G-7 presidency in 2018, and then picked up by France during its 2019 G-7 presidency. The U.S. joined in May 2020.
With the U.S. joinder, the GPAI launched as a multistakeholder initiative that includes 18 countries and the EU. It is perhaps the most comprehensive effort to establish a common understanding and approach to AI. GPAI has four working groups of stakeholders and officials focused on Responsible Development, Use and Governance of AI, Data Governance, Innovation and Commercialization, and the Future of Work. This structure is valuable for its incorporation of nongovernmental stakeholders and experts into the workstreams.
The broader G-20, which includes China, Russia, and Saudi Arabia, also has made AI a subject of discussions. Key outcomes include a set of AI principles (based on the OECD AI Principles) as part of the 2019 Osaka G-20 and ongoing G-20 work that focuses on developing a human-centered approach to AI. Related G-20 work affirming the importance of data free flow with trust and data flows is also important for AI development.
The 37-member OECD has several strands of AI-related work. Through its consultative processes, it developed the recommended policy principles adopted by its Council of Ministers, which are reflected in the G-20 statement and present a useful consensus on broad AI issues. The OECD continues to do research to inform government AI policies and it operates an observatory that tracks policy developments, research, and data available via a web portal. It also functions as the secretariat for GPAI.

The multilateral and multistakeholder forums for AI governance and cooperation discussed above offer advantages and disadvantages. The G-7 and G-20 provide opportunities for leaders to discuss technology and AI issues. The latter produced some high-level agreement on principles while the former spawned GPAI, which has the potential to help put principles into practice. However, the inclusion of China and Russia in the G-20 will limit the extent to which that body can drive effective international cooperation on AI as well as other technology issues. And when it comes to a discussion on technology and AI issues, the G-7 overrepresents European countries based on GDP and not technology leadership. The OECD provides a broader forum with significant multistakeholder input and excellent thought leadership, but lacks the chief-of-government engagement of the other groups.
Rather than bet on one horse for international engagement on AI (and related issues), the U.S. should play the field, seeking out like-minded partners and the best pathways for specific issues and building outward where it can. The U.S. should also consider convening a broader annual leaders-level meeting focused on international cooperation on technology issues including AI. There are various configurations for such a meeting but it should include the U.S., Canada, U.K., EU, Germany, France, Japan, Australia, Singapore, and Chile (and possibly Taiwan, South Korea, and India).
The recommendations that follow are based on three interrelated goals that should be a focus for the new administration and its international engagement on technology and AI: (1) developing avenues of cooperation for global development of AI, (2) effective alignment with the EU on AI, and (3) addressing the China challenge.
### Deployment of AI for good

excerpts:
For many emerging economies, AI adoption is not merely a technology shift, but a matter of digital sovereignty. Many governments increasingly recognise the risks of over-reliance on foreign AI providers, including data security vulnerabilities and economic dependencies that could limit their strategic autonomy. In response, nations such as India and Brazil are investing in domestic AI capabilities, while regional bodies like the African Union are crafting governance frameworks that align AI adoption with local ethical and regulatory principles.
### Strategic A.I. Autonomy: A U.S. Path to Competing Without Forcing Dependence
Rather than retreating from multilateral governance, the US should champion strategic AI autonomy, not full detachment from global AI ecosystems, but ensuring that nations have access to trusted and diversified AI models that do not force them into dependence on China’s AI infrastructure. This does not mean undermining US AI firms, but rather shaping AI partnerships that provide market access while offering a compelling alternative to China’s state-backed AI exports. A balanced strategy would focus on capacity-building partnerships, secure cloud-based AI platforms and interoperable AI ecosystems that allow emerging economies to develop their own AI capabilities while still benefiting from US-led innovation and infrastructure.
A balanced strategy would focus on capacity-building partnerships, secure cloud-based AI platforms and interoperable AI ecosystems that allow emerging economies to develop their own AI capabilities while still benefiting from US-led innovation and infrastructure.

Some nations are also leveraging AI to strengthen regional cooperation. , for instance, is developing a regional AI framework to establish standardised governance policies across member states. This initiative aims to balance AI adoption with regulatory oversight, preventing monopolistic control by any single external actor, whether China or the US. Similarly, Latin American nations are collaborating on AI ethics guidelines tailored to their socio-economic contexts, ensuring that AI development aligns with national interests, rather than foreign corporate or geopolitical imperatives.
By sidelining multilateral AI governance, Washington risks not only losing influence to Beijing but also neglecting the growing demand from the Global South for AI models and policies that reflect their economic realities and governance priorities. Given that developing nations represent the majority in multilateral discussions, their choices will shape the future of AI governance. If the US fails to engage, emerging economies will look elsewhere, shaping an AI trajectory that does not align with US and its allies’ strategic interests.
If the US fails to engage, emerging economies will look elsewhere, shaping an AI trajectory that does not align with US and its allies’ strategic interests.
### A.I. Leadership: Will the U.S. Cede the Future to China?
The future of AI geopolitics will not be dictated solely by the US or China, but by the choices of the emerging AI economies of the Global South. However, as Washington retreats from multilateral AI diplomacy and fails to offer compelling alternatives, China is rapidly filling the vacuum. Through strategic investments, scalable AI solutions and deepening technological dependencies, Beijing is embedding its influence in the digital infrastructure and governance frameworks of the Global South.

Nations in Africa, Latin America and Southeast Asia are setting regulatory precedents, developing homegrown AI capabilities, and influencing global AI norms in multilateral institutions. For instance, [Brazil’s AI strategy](https://www.gov.br/mcti/pt-br/acompanhe-o-mcti/transformacaodigital/arquivosinteligenciaartificial/ebia-summary_brazilian_4-979_2021.pdf) emphasises ethical AI governance and innovation in agriculture, while [Indonesia’s AI roadmap](https://www.google.com/search?client=safari&rls=en&q=Indonesia%E2%80%99s+Stranas+KA+AI+strategy&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8) focuses on workforce transformation and smart cities. Meanwhile, Kenya has positioned itself as a leader in [AI-driven financial inclusion](https://www.undp.org/africa/stories/breaking-barriers-powering-financial-inclusion-africa-ai), leveraging machine learning for mobile banking and digital payments. Beyond policy, these regions offer AI models unique training environments that enhance adaptability and efficiency. AI-driven medical diagnostics, such as [Google’s tuberculosis detection AI](https://blog.google/technology/health/ai-model-cough-disease-detection/) trained on African medical datasets, have demonstrated improved accuracy in local healthcare settings. In Latin America, [AI-powered climate prediction](https://farmonaut.com/south-america/revolutionizing-brazilian-agriculture-how-ai-and-agritech-startups-are-transforming-farming-in-2023/) and crop disease detection models are being refined using agriculture data tailored to smallholder farmers’ needs. Meanwhile, natural language processing models training on Southeast Asian languages, such as those from the project, are improving AI-driven translation and speech recognition for multilingual populations.
As AI becomes deeply integrated into governance, security and economic planning, how these countries choose to align, whether with China, the US, or a diversified approach, will heavily influence the future structure of global AI power.

excerpts: This paper discusses the critical role of international partnerships and alliances in promoting AI-driven healthcare initiatives. These collaborations have the potential to address pressing challenges such as healthcare workforce shortages, disparities in access to care, and the growing demand for personalized healthcare services. By pooling resources, expertise, and technology, international partnerships can facilitate the development and deployment of AI solutions tailored to the unique needs of different regions. For example, partnerships can enable the co-creation of datasets that are more representative of diverse populations, thereby improving the fairness and generalizability of AI models. Additionally, joint initiatives can support the sharing of best practices and lessons learned, ensuring that low-resource settings benefit from innovations pioneered in high-resource environments. Such collaborations also provide opportunities for capacity building through training programs and knowledge transfer, empowering local healthcare professionals and organizations to leverage AI effectively. Furthermore, global alliances can play a pivotal role in addressing ethical and regulatory challenges, fostering trust and ensuring the responsible use of AI in healthcare. Through these efforts, international partnerships can bridge the gap between technological innovation and real-world impact, driving equitable access to quality healthcare services worldwide.

Addressing these challenges requires a collaborative and inclusive approach that bridges the technological divide. International partnerships are essential in fostering knowledge exchange, enabling low-resource settings to benefit from the expertise and advancements of more technologically advanced nations. Such collaborations can support capacity building through training programs, workshops, and mentorship initiatives aimed at equipping local professionals with the skills needed to implement and adapt AI-driven healthcare solutions. Furthermore, partnerships can facilitate technology transfer by adapting AI tools to local contexts, ensuring they address region-specific health challenges. By sharing best practices and co-creating solutions, international alliances can accelerate the equitable deployment of AI in healthcare, ultimately contributing to global efforts toward achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), particularly SDG 3 on good health and well-being.
##  3. International Partnerships for AI-Driven Healthcare
Note on Methodology: The international initiatives highlighted in this paper were identified through a targeted review of peer-reviewed publications, policy reports, and institutional websites published between 2020 and early 2024. Selection criteria included geographic diversity, relevance to AI in healthcare, documented multi-stakeholder collaboration, and evidence of impact or scalability. Where possible, initiatives supported by intergovernmental organizations (e.g., WHO, UN agencies), academic–industry consortia, or large-scale public programs were prioritized. While this is not a systematic review, efforts were made to reduce selection bias and provide a representative overview of global efforts in AI-driven healthcare collaboration.
### 3.1. Technology Transfer and Capacity Building

Partnerships between developed and developing countries play a crucial role in facilitating the transfer of AI technologies and expertise, thereby narrowing the global gap in AI adoption for healthcare []. For instance, collaborations between academic institutions in high-income and low-income countries help build local capacity in AI by providing access to resources, training, and technical mentorship. One notable example is the partnership between Imperial College London and universities in sub-Saharan Africa [], focusing on training healthcare professionals in AI and data science to address pressing local healthcare challenges, such as infectious disease outbreaks and maternal health. By co-developing AI-driven solutions, this collaboration ensures that the technologies are contextually relevant and can effectively address regional needs. Similarly, the MIT Abdul Latif Jameel Clinic for Machine Learning in Health has partnered with institutions in South Asia to provide training programs and resources for the implementation of AI solutions in areas such as early disease detection and healthcare logistics []. These partnerships emphasize not only the transfer of technology but also the creation of sustainable ecosystems by enabling local researchers and practitioners to take ownership of AI projects. For example, these initiatives have empowered local healthcare providers to develop predictive models for disease outbreaks using region-specific data, significantly improving response times during crises.

node_9.literature_writeup:
# Constraints and Vulnerabilities in Global AI Development

## Introduction
Artificial intelligence (AI) development across leading nations—namely the United States, China, and the European Union—faces multiple technological and geopolitical constraints. Chief among these are dependencies and restrictions tied to semiconductor production and export controls, which determine access to the advanced computational resources necessary for AI training and deployment. Each region’s vulnerabilities emerge from different strategic contexts, yet all reflect the increasingly intertwined nature of global AI supply chains.

## United States: Strategic Control Through Export Restrictions
The United States employs export controls as a primary mechanism for maintaining its technological dominance and protecting national security. These measures have expanded in scope and complexity over the past decade. Since 2010, the U.S. has imposed restrictions on supercomputer chips and semiconductors integral to AI development, and by 2022, the country intensified these efforts to encompass advanced chips, design software, and manufacturing equipment. Continuing expansions of these controls as of 2024 illustrate the evolving nature of AI-related regulation [1][2].

Central to these efforts is the Foreign Direct Product Rule, granting the U.S. jurisdiction over foreign-manufactured items that incorporate American technology. This rule effectively extends U.S. regulatory power beyond domestic borders, complicating international supply chains and impeding the flow of advanced hardware to strategic competitors such as China. As a result, companies requiring high-performance GPUs like Nvidia’s H800 and A100 face increasing obstacles when operating in or supplying restricted regions [1][2].

While these policies aim to slow adversaries’ technological advancement, they also generate indirect constraints for U.S. firms by tightening supply chain flexibility and prompting global retaliatory responses or diversification efforts. The U.S. thus faces the challenge of balancing national security objectives with maintaining innovation fluidity in its domestic AI sector [1][2].

## China: Hardware Dependence and Adaptive Mitigation Strategies
China’s primary constraint lies in its dependency on foreign—especially American—hardware. Despite commitments to achieving self-sufficiency through a national AI stack and domestic semiconductor production, these ambitions are undermined by continuing exposure to export restrictions. Advanced chip manufacturing, critical for large-scale AI model training, remains hindered by limited access to extreme ultraviolet (EUV) lithography tools. For instance, Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation (SMIC) has struggled to scale 7nm chip production without EUV access, resulting in limited wafer volumes and curtailing broader chip ecosystem expansion [1][2].

Chinese AI developers have responded by pursuing technological workarounds. Firms such as DeepSeek have refined optimization techniques that enable AI models to run efficiently on less powerful hardware. Although these programming adaptations partially offset hardware deficits, they divert skilled engineering talent away from core innovation goals, thereby diminishing overall R&D efficiency. Consequently, while China remains resilient in adapting to imposed constraints, its efforts highlight a structural vulnerability: the redirection of creative and technical resources toward coping mechanisms rather than frontier development [1][2].

## European Union: Dual Dependency and Strategic Vulnerability
The European Union faces a distinctive two-tiered dependency structure in its AI ecosystem. At the first level, Europe relies heavily on U.S.-origin AI chips, particularly those produced by Nvidia, which controls an estimated 80–90% of the global GPU market. The continent’s emerging AI Gigafactories thus depend on consistent supply access from American providers, making them susceptible to disruptions stemming from U.S. export regulations or market shortages [3][4].

At a second level, Europe is exposed to the geopolitical dynamics surrounding critical minerals, a majority of which are sourced from China. This dual reliance—on U.S. chip technology and Chinese raw materials—creates systemic fragility in Europe’s AI supply chain, constraining its pursuit of technological autonomy and sovereignty [4].

In recognition of these vulnerabilities, the European Commission has championed initiatives aimed at stabilizing and diversifying AI hardware supply lines. Efforts such as the EU-U.S. Critical Tech and Dual-Use Council are intended to address transatlantic tech dependencies and coordinate semiconductor policy. Likewise, European semiconductor manufacturers have shifted toward “just-in-case” inventory models, supplier diversification, and investment in emerging fabrication technologies such as 3D chip stacking and silicon photonics. These strategic mitigations, however, are expected to yield only incremental near-term benefits given the entrenched dominance of foreign suppliers [3][4].

## Global Supply Chain Fragmentation and Geopolitical Contestation
Across all three major powers, AI supply chains are characterized by fragmentation and strategic tension. The U.S. dominates GPU design and controls critical equipment through export regimes, while China commands access to key minerals underpinning semiconductor production. This asymmetry underscores a broader structural rupture in global AI development, where geopolitical rivalry directly translates into technological constraint [4].

In practical terms, these dynamics expose mutual vulnerabilities: U.S. regulatory measures can slow competitors but also risk over-concentration of production; Chinese self-reliance strategies may achieve incremental progress but cannot yet substitute for high-end Western technology; and the European Union’s pursuit of strategic autonomy is undermined by its limited leverage across the semiconductor value chain. The resulting global environment is one defined by competition under interdependence, where strategic regulation, technological dependency, and policy coordination collectively shape the trajectory of AI advancement [1][2][3][4].
node_9.report:
# Geopolitical Rivalries and Export Controls Shape Global AI Supply Chain Dynamics

## The AI Industry’s Dependence on Advanced Semiconductor Technologies

The foundation of modern artificial intelligence lies in specialized semiconductor hardware. Training large-scale AI models, such as language models or autonomous system networks, depends heavily on advanced chips—AI-specific GPUs, high-performance CPUs, and dedicated accelerators. Control over these technologies determines which nations can push the boundaries of innovation, as supply chains for these chips are globally interlinked and technically complex [1][2][3][4].

The industry’s concentration in a few technological centers makes it vulnerable to geopolitical pressures. Semiconductor production involves a multi-tiered global process—from raw material mining to chip design to advanced manufacturing, a chain that depends on critical nodes scattered across the U.S., East Asia, and Europe. As AI capabilities become central to economic and military power, these dependencies have transformed into strategic assets weaponized through export restrictions and regulatory controls.

## U.S. Export Controls and Technological Dominance Strategy

The United States has leveraged export controls as a key tool of geopolitical strategy to preserve its lead in AI and semiconductor technologies. Since 2010, Washington has imposed successive restrictions on the export of supercomputer chips and AI-related semiconductors to maintain national security and technological leadership. Beginning in 2022 and extending through 2024, these controls expanded to include advanced semiconductors, design software, and chip manufacturing equipment. Their explicit goal is to limit China’s access to high-end AI training infrastructure, particularly Nvidia GPUs such as the A100 and H800, essential for building large language models [1][2].

These controls are enforced not only domestically but globally, thanks to the Foreign Direct Product Rule, which extends U.S. regulatory reach to foreign-made products containing U.S. technology. The result is a complex compliance environment where even non-American firms must follow American export restrictions, further amplifying U.S. influence over the global AI supply chain [2].  

Through these mechanisms, the United States strategically channels high-end chip availability to allied markets while isolating perceived competitors. This approach not only protects technological secrets but also reinforces U.S. leadership in crucial AI development tools.

## China’s Technological Vulnerabilities and Adaptive Strategies

China stands at a critical junction between ambition and constraint. Despite ambitious plans for self-reliance in AI hardware and chip manufacturing, it remains dependent on foreign-made semiconductors and production equipment. U.S.-imposed export controls have significantly hindered China’s capacity to manufacture cutting-edge chips. Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation (SMIC), China’s leading foundry, has managed to achieve limited 7nm production capabilities but lacks access to the EUV lithography machines essential for scalable advanced chip fabrication. This bottleneck limits output and hampers China’s goal of building a vertically integrated AI technology stack [1][2].

Chinese firms, however, have demonstrated adaptive resilience. Companies like DeepSeek have optimized code and algorithmic architectures to maximize efficiency on less powerful GPUs, effectively compensating for hardware deficits. Yet, this adaptation consumes valuable engineering talent that could otherwise accelerate new AI model development. The long-term result is a diversion of resources away from foundational AI innovation toward mitigation of imposed technological restrictions [1][2].

Despite these constraints, China continues to invest heavily in research, local fabrication, and alternative architectures, signaling a broader race toward indigenization. However, absent access to critical manufacturing inputs, such as Western lithography systems and design tools, full self-sufficiency remains an uphill task.

## The European Union’s Dependency and Strategic Dilemmas

The European Union, while not directly a combatant in the technology rivalry, finds itself entangled in the U.S.-China competition due to structural dependence on U.S. chip technologies. The continent’s AI research and industrial systems overwhelmingly rely on GPUs and hardware designed by American firms, with Nvidia alone controlling roughly 80–90% of the global AI GPU market [3]. Consequently, Europe’s emerging AI Gigafactories operate within the constraints of supply chains tightly linked to U.S. export control frameworks.

This dependency introduces vulnerabilities. Should regulatory shifts or geopolitical tensions disrupt U.S. supply lines, Europe would face severe capacity shortages in its AI infrastructure. Aware of these risks, the European Commission has prioritized strategic autonomy initiatives, promoting diversification of technology supply chains and greater investment in regional fabrication capabilities [3][4]. Collaborative mechanisms such as the EU-U.S. Critical Tech and Dual-Use Council seek to stabilize flows of essential semiconductor components and mitigate transatlantic friction [3].

To counter immediate risks, European firms have adopted “just-in-case” inventory models and explored new chip technologies like 3D stacking and silicon photonics to improve efficiency and reduce reliance on single-nation suppliers. Yet, such adjustments only modestly alleviate short-term exposure to global disruption [4].

## A Fragile and Interdependent AI Ecosystem

Underlying these regional challenges is a structurally fragile global ecosystem. The semiconductor and AI industries depend on a transnational mix of resources: the U.S. dominates chip design and high-end GPU production, East Asia hosts key fabrication capacity, and China controls substantial portions of the supply of vital rare-earth minerals. Europe, in turn, remains doubly dependent—on U.S. chips and on Chinese raw materials—creating a dual-layered strategic vulnerability [4].

This interdependence transforms AI innovation into a politically charged domain. Export controls intended to protect national security simultaneously fracture global technological collaboration, creating bottlenecks that threaten the pace of AI advancement worldwide. Each region’s efforts to reinforce self-reliance risk fragmenting the innovation chain that currently sustains global AI progress.

## Future Scenarios: Decoupling, Regionalization, and Cooperative Frameworks

As supply chain vulnerabilities deepen, nations are confronting difficult strategic choices. One potential trajectory is decoupling—where rival blocs cultivate independent ecosystems insulated from foreign control. Another approach is regionalization of manufacturing, aligning production with politically trusted regional partners. Alternatively, multilateral governance frameworks, such as expanded technology compacts or critical minerals agreements, could stabilize cooperation despite underlying competition.

Balancing sovereignty with interdependence remains the defining challenge. Whether through isolation or collaboration, the trajectory of AI development in the coming years will be dictated not just by innovation, but by the geopolitical architecture surrounding the semiconductor supply chain [1][2][3][4].

[1]. https://laweconcenter.org/resources/us-export-controls-on-ai-and-semiconductors-two-divergent-visions/

excerpts:
### Hardware export controls will impact China’s trajectory
No discussion of the prospects for an indigenization of China’s AI stack would be complete without considering external factors – specifically, foreign governments’ export controls and their likely impact on the country’s AI ecosystem. In October 2022, the US introduced unilateral export controls on certain semiconductors, chip design software, and chip-making equipment. Those controls were beefed up in 2023 and again in 2024.
So far, Chinese LLM developers have managed to access American-designed GPUs to train and deploy their models. To train the R1, DeepSeek claimed to have used merely 2,048 Nvidia H800 GPUs, which Washington only banned in October 2023. DeepSeek reportedly also had access to 10,000 of the less powerful A100 GPUs. Others estimate the company had access to many more Nvidia GPUs, and some in Congress have launched a probe into possible smuggling. In a nutshell, export controls are not perfect firewalls, and Washington could tighten the screws further. US firms will keep adjusting to this: Nvidia is due to release a downgraded version of its H20 to keep servicing Chinese customers.

* China’s experience shows that state-led approaches have limitations. Private companies that initially take off with limited state connections or support, like DeepSeek, can often be the most disruptive. In contrast, efforts to bend the choices of AI firms and developers to techno-nationalist agendas rarely bear fruit.
  * Geopolitical competition will continue to shape Europe’s choices. The US and China both aim for dominance in AI and their ecosystems are bifurcating. Reliance on US hardware could expose Europe to supply constraints or even coercion. But alternatives like Huawei’s AI chips, besides technical difficulties, may present security risks or even be in breach of US export controls.

The US has identified AI and the semiconductor technologies that enable its advancements as among several general-purpose “force-multipliers”, and US leadership as a “national security imperative.” Accordingly, Washington has rolled out policies aimed at slowing China’s AI development, primarily through export controls on advanced semiconductors needed to train AI models, as well as on the software and equipment used to manufacture those chips.
China’s leaders similarly view advancements in AI as key to national security and overall competitiveness, and they have characterized it as a strategic emerging field that offers the country a historic opportunity to leapfrog the US economically and militarily. Beijing published its first national AI strategy in 2017, outlining steps to become a “major AI innovation center in the world.” US export controls have reinforced Beijing’s conviction that China’s dependency on foreign countries – particularly the US – for its AI future is a national security risk.
China is arguably the first country trying to develop a national AI stack, but some in Europe have recently articulated this objective, too. So, where is China now in terms of AI chips, frameworks and applications? Who are the most important players? How is the government shaping the development and adoption of homegrown technology? How does this differ across the stack and why?
Understanding China’s AI progress is crucial for European policymakers trying to navigate technology competition – for example to predict US export controls that might affect European companies. It can also help decision makers assess where Europe has leverage and how to engage, including companies that are increasingly embedding local solutions in their offerings for the Chinese market.

excerpts:
Export controls must distinguish between computational power (commonly referred to as “compute”) used for training new AI models and for inference (deploying existing models). While training frontier models requires enormous compute resources, inference (running those models) also demands significant hardware, especially for advanced reasoning capabilities. Nathan Lambert points out that reasoning models like OpenAI’s o1 require especially significant amounts of computational power.
One counterargument to export controls comes from China’s demonstrated ability to optimize AI systems under hardware constraints. DeepSeek’s R1 model achieved capabilities competitive with OpenAI’s o1 despite being forced by U.S. sanctions to use less-powerful H800 GPUs with constrained memory bandwidth.
AI investor Nat Friedman poses the question: 
> is it in fact the case that, if you impose sanctions on China so that they can’t get as much compute, then all you do is give them this constraint to optimize against, which says, ‘How can we squeeze every little bit of IQ out of every flop that we’ve got?’, and they just find clever ways of doing a lot more with a lot less.25
> Ben Thompson, _An Interview with Daniel Gross and Nat Friedman About Models, Margins, and Moats_ , Stratechery (Jan. 23, 2025), .
But optimization of this kind also produces tradeoffs; a company that focuses on optimization does so at the expense of putting their scarce top engineers on other tasks. It is at least possible that U.S. researchers who do not face such constraints will use their time to develop even better AI applications.
#### 3. Manufacturing challenges beyond EUV

The export controls invoke the Foreign Direct Product Rule (FDPR) to extend U.S. jurisdiction over foreign-made items that incorporate U.S. technology, or that were manufactured using U.S. equipment. As Gregory Allen notes, the December 2024 update to the U.S. export controls even created “new FDPRs and updated provisions” that expanded unilateral U.S. authority, potentially capturing “all of the SME made by any company on Earth.”
These restrictions have created a complex set of responses and adaptations. While they have slowed China’s advancement at the cutting edge, they haven’t stopped it entirely. As Allen noted, “SMIC was already producing and selling 7nm chips no later than July 2022 and potentially as early as July 2021, despite having no EUV machines.”
But the controls have “dramatically constrained SMIC’s ability to scale up 7nm production,” limiting output to the “low tens of thousands” of wafers monthly, instead of the “hundreds of thousands” originally planned. 
The restrictions have also spurred efficiency innovations. DeepSeek, for example, developed advanced techniques to overcome bandwidth limitations in the H800 chips they could legally access, programming “20 of the 132 processing units on each H800 specifically to manage cross-chip communications” by working at a lower programming level than Nvidia’s CUDA (for “Compute Unified Device Architecture”) parallel-computing platform.
Such adaptations reflect China’s determination to progress in AI development, despite the constraints imposed by U.S. export controls.

cited_documents.title: Securing the AI chips supply and value network
cited_documents.reason_for_retrieval: What are the main technological and supply chain constraints (such as export controls and chip dependencies) faced by the United States, China, and the European Union in AI development?

excerpts:
The AI revolution may appear ethereal and software-driven, epitomized by Large Language Models (LLMs). Yet its foundations are profoundly material, resting on powerful data centers, cutting-edge AI chips, and critical minerals — all embedded in fragile supply chains that are anything but virtual.
A defining feature of these supply chains is their geostrategic rupture between the world’s two greatest powers. The United States dominates advanced AI GPU design and production, while China controls the supply and processing of rare earth elements (REEs). Both increasingly weaponize their leverage in the escalating „chip war” to outcompete the other in the AI race.
The collateral — but also deliberate — damage falls on Europe, which finds itself trapped in a deepening two-level dependency. This comes at a time when the continent is mobilizing resources to close the gap in AI development by heavily investing in advanced, large-scale hardware infrastructure. At its core lie AI factories: massive data and compute facilities that provide the processing power and storage needed to train, test, and scale Large Language Models (LLMs) and other AI systems.
Today, the US and China dominate the global AI infrastructure landscape, jointly operating more than 90% of all AI factories. The implication is clear: Europe lacks the scale and capacity needed to develop and deploy its own AI models at a competitive pace.
For this reason, the EU and its member states have stepped up investments in AI factories, with at least 15 facilities expected to be operational by the end of next year. At the center of this push is the EU’s flagship plan to build up to five AI Gigafactories — each equipped with around 100,000 AI chips and costing between €3 and €5 billion — several times more than the capacity and expense of existing facilities.

## First level dependency: US AI chips
Europe’s first, and most visible, dependency lies in its near-total reliance on American AI chips. AI factories are, in essence, clusters of thousands of these processors. The most widely used among them are AI GPUs (Graphics Processing Units), specialized chips designed to handle the massively parallel computations required to train and run advanced AI models.
It is the US-based company NVIDIA that dominates the market, controlling an estimated 80–90% of global AI GPU sales. Unsurprisingly, the company produces the world’s most advanced processors, like NVIDIA Blackwell Ultra GPUs, which are considered indispensable for training the highest-performing LLMs. As a result, the GPUs powering Europe’s future AI Gigafactories will almost certainly come from NVIDIA.
Therefore, the fast completion and competitiveness of EU factories are conditioned on an uninterrupted and abundant supply of the most advanced NVIDIA GPUs from the US. Yet there are plenty of reasons why Europe should expect shortages and delays in their provision.
History has already shown how vulnerable this supply can be. In its final days, the Biden administration established the Framework for Artificial Intelligence Diffusion, imposing export controls on advanced AI chips through a three-tier country system. Although the policy was aimed primarily at US adversaries such as China, Russia, and their closest allies, many EU member states in Central and Eastern Europe would also have faced controlled access.
Eventually, the new Trump administration revoked the framework while simultaneously negotiating the EU’s intention to purchase at least $40 billion worth of US AI chips for its computing centers. The move underscores Washington’s interest in maintaining Europe’s dependency: it reinforces NVIDIA’s market dominance while preserving another strategic lever over the EU.
cited_documents.title: Trapped in the Chip War: Europe's AI ambitions at risk

node_10.question: What metrics or indicators can be used to define 'winning' the AI arms race (e.g., military capability, economic dominance, research leadership)?

node_10.literature_writeup:
# Metrics for Defining ‘Winning’ the AI Arms Race

The concept of "winning" the AI arms race encompasses multiple strategic domains, particularly military capability, economic competitiveness, and technological leadership. Because AI is a general-purpose technology with dual-use potential, traditional military or economic dominance metrics alone are insufficient. Therefore, the assessment of advantage relies on integrated indicators of research, innovation, technological infrastructure, and operational adoption.

## Military Capability Metrics

### Core Indicators of AI-Driven Military Advantage

The primary metrics used to assess national advantage in the AI arms race's military dimension include the number of deployed military systems utilizing AI, the scale of research and development (R&D) spending on AI-related technologies, and the strength of manufacturing capabilities supporting AI hardware and software [1][2]. These indicators collectively measure a country's ability to develop, implement, and sustain AI-based defense technologies and systems at scale.

The United States, for example, recorded approximately $5 billion in defense AI R&D in fiscal year 2020, constituting around 0.7% of the Department of Defense budget [2]. While this investment indicates a robust military AI initiative, its comparative modesty to conventional arms expenditures highlights a critical complexity: AI competition cannot be captured merely through budgetary growth. The AI arms race’s intangible nature—centering on software, algorithms, and data capabilities—necessitates reliance on multifactorial indicators rather than direct commodity counts [2].

### Technological and Economic Foundations Supporting Military Capability

Beyond military expenditure, other critical indicators include the number and expertise of AI researchers, investment volumes in AI startups, and production capacities for core AI-enabling technologies such as semiconductors and GPUs [1][3]. These components form the foundation for scalable AI deployment within defense ecosystems and signal the broader national preparedness for AI-integrated military operations.

Comparative data shows that the United States leads in both the number of AI researchers and investments tied to critical technological infrastructure, while China demonstrates strength in state-backed funding and AI startup investments. The latter includes government-led initiatives amounting to approximately $200 billion over a decade, spanning civilian, commercial, and military AI development [1][3]. Such massive state investment magnifies China’s ability to sustain a long-term technological race, while U.S. advantage currently stems from private-sector innovation and academic leadership.

### Strategic Capabilities and Operational Integration

Military AI advantage also depends heavily on cyber defense capacities, election security resilience, and the effectiveness of automated decision-making systems implemented in critical national sectors [3]. These dimensions represent both assets and vulnerabilities, directly influencing a nation’s strategic standing in AI-enabled warfare contexts.

In addition, the degree of coordination and interoperability among allied nations through cooperative AI governance and shared technological standards is emerging as a significant determinant of power projection. Such collaborations can create network effects in data sharing and system compatibility, enhancing the collective capability of participating nations [3].

### Measuring Intangible Advantage: Innovation and Integration

Unlike traditional armament stockpiles, AI capability cannot be reduced to the number of discrete artifacts produced or deployed. Its software-centric and dual-use nature blurs distinctions between civilian innovations and defense applications, making national advantage a function of factors such as innovation pace, integration efficiency, and ecosystem flexibility [1][4]. Therefore, assessing “winning” in the AI military domain necessitates composite metrics built around technological innovation rates, R&D intensity, control of hardware supply chains, and workforce expertise.

### Summary of Military Metrics

In conclusion, the key military metrics defining national advancement in the AI arms race include:
- Quantity and sophistication of deployed AI-enabled military systems  
- Total and relative national AI R&D spending, both defense-specific and dual-use  
- Scale and independence of semiconductor and hardware manufacturing  
- Investment levels in AI startups relevant to defense infrastructure  
- Number and quality of AI researchers and engineers  
- Robustness of cyber defense systems and critical infrastructure protection  
- Depth of integration of AI across military command and operational networks  
- Cooperation and alignment with allies on AI standards and governance mechanisms [1][2][3]

Together, these metrics depict a multidimensional framework in which traditional military strength intersects with technological innovation capacity, shaping how nations pursue strategic superiority in AI-driven defense landscapes.
node_10.report:
# Measuring National Power in the Global Artificial Intelligence Arms Race

## The Emergence of the Global AI Arms Competition

The development of artificial intelligence (AI) has introduced a new strategic front in both economic and military competition among world powers. Nations increasingly perceive AI as a transformative force capable of reshaping defense strategy, economic structure, and global influence. In this environment, the ability to harness and integrate AI into defense operations, decision-making, and infrastructure becomes a measure of future national power. However, unlike traditional arms buildups centered on tangible weapons systems, the AI arms race operates across diffuse technological and governance domains, complicating efforts to measure national advantage [1][2].

## Defining National Advantage in AI

National advantage within the AI arms race arises from the combined strength of military applications, research ecosystems, industrial capacity, and governance competency. These dimensions reinforce each other: military deployment relies on innovation pipelines; innovation depends on talent, data, and hardware; and sustainable progress requires effective governance to coordinate efforts across sectors [1][3][4].  

An AI-capable nation therefore possesses more than weapons platforms—it demonstrates the infrastructure to sustain technological leadership, protect against digital vulnerabilities, and integrate AI safely into national defense and economic systems. 

## Key Assessment Metrics

### Deployment of AI-Enabled Military Systems

One of the primary metrics of national capability is the extent to which AI-enabled systems are deployed across armed forces. This includes autonomous vehicles, AI-assisted surveillance, predictive maintenance systems, and command and control algorithms. Because AI is software-based and dual-use, counting such systems provides only partial insight, reflecting integration quality rather than mere quantity [1][4]. The United States, for instance, deploys a range of AI-supported decision-making and logistics tools but maintains a modest share of its overall defense budget—roughly $5 billion in fiscal year 2020, or 0.7% of total Department of Defense spending—on AI research and development [2].  

### Defense R&D Spending and Industrial Output

R&D expenditures and industrial capabilities remain fundamental indicators of AI defense strength. The U.S. devotes substantial resources to defense-related AI R&D, while China’s government-driven investment strategy covers both military and commercial AI development. Over the past decade, Chinese state-backed initiatives have injected approximately $200 billion across AI domains, resulting in rapid capability growth [1][3]. Yet overall military AI spending globally remains small relative to traditional arms races, indicating that AI advantage cannot be measured purely through budgetary increases [2].  

### AI Talent and Research Capacity

The number and proficiency of AI researchers form another major element of strategic advantage. The United States leads in global research output and educational pipelines for AI specialists, while China shows acceleration in both domestic training and recruitment of foreign-trained experts [1][3]. The distribution of talent determines not only innovation potential but also a nation’s ability to operationalize AI in defense contexts.  

### Semiconductor and Hardware Capabilities

Control over semiconductor manufacturing and high-performance computing resources constitutes a critical determinant of AI competitiveness. AI development depends on advanced chips, GPUs, and the infrastructure enabling large-scale computation. National production capabilities directly influence a country’s independence in sustaining AI systems, with the United States and its allies currently retaining a manufacturing edge in high-end chips, while China strives to close this gap through domestic investments [1][3].  

### Cyber Defense and Security Resilience

Cyber defense systems—and their integration with AI threat detection and response technologies—represent both an indicator and a determinant of national AI preparedness. AI increases both attack and defense potential in cyberspace, thereby elevating the importance of secure digital infrastructure. National abilities to protect critical sectors, election systems, and communications against AI-driven threats are now recognized as core components of defense readiness [3].  

### Governance, Collaboration, and Innovation Ecosystems

Governance structures and cooperative frameworks substantially shape AI advantage. National policies that align military, civilian, and private-sector initiatives encourage strategic coherence and reduce redundancy. International collaborations around standards and interoperability reinforce shared norms of accountability while amplifying defensive power among allied nations [3]. Ultimately, governance determines how efficiently research, industry, and defense institutions translate technological progress into strategic outcomes.  

## Comparative Strategic Capacity Among Leading Nations

When the above metrics are viewed together, a layered picture of AI power emerges. The United States maintains dominance in research excellence, semiconductor control, and alliance networks; China excels in state-directed investment and application scaling; while other nations—such as those in Europe—leverage regulatory sophistication and cooperative governance initiatives. Each model embodies different interpretations of how technological maturity contributes to national strength, underscoring that AI advantage derives from systemic coordination rather than single-point superiority [1][2][3][4].  

## The Limits and Evolution of AI Power Metrics

Measuring military capability in AI remains challenging due to the technology’s dual-use nature and software-centric form. Traditional count-based methods, suitable for missiles or aircraft, fail to capture the distributed and adaptive character of AI innovation. Instead, more nuanced hybrid models that combine indicators of R&D intensity, deployment reach, hardware control, and governance integration are necessary [1][2][4]. As AI evolves, so too must the frameworks used to assess national power—shifting from static inventories to dynamic systems capable of representing the intertwined influence of technology, policy, and human expertise.

## Bibliography

[1]. https://tnsr.org/2021/06/debunking-the-ai-arms-race-theory/

excerpts:
Technology development is not weapons manufacturing. We need new terms for AI competition. 
Military metaphors are a symptom of intellectual laziness. “AI arms race” is an example. AI is not an arm, nor does the possession of advanced AI guarantee strategic advantage. The image of an arms race is stale and obscures the complexity of AI’s effects and the processes that create it. A new vocabulary would better guide policy and help Washington and other capitals better understand the processes, effects, and challenges of technology, disruption and innovation.
Declarations that there is an “arms race” are usually tools of political rhetoric, used to press for more spending, to criticize incumbents, or to appeal for measures to reduce perceived risks. Using the arms race metaphor for AI raises several questions. If this is a race, how do we measure who is ahead? What are the right metrics to gauge national AI success? How does better AI translate into tangible national power? Precedents from the last century are unpromising as a source of answers to these questions.
The idea of an “arms race” became prominent in the late 19 century, when Britain and its European competitors began an intense competition for naval supremacy. Each competitor built powerful ships; the British to maintain their naval advantage and the others to match or surpass Britain. “Arm Race” reappeared in the 1930s as German rearmament triggered unease and last-minute arms buildups in the US and UK. In the 1950s and 1960s, the arms race was driven by the acquisition of nuclear weapons and their delivery systems (and accompanied by periodic claims that the US was falling behind the Soviets).

Arms races are an effort to preserve stability by ensuring balance in military capabilities among opponents. Past arms races involved building new weapons that were believed to confer military superiority. One side begins to build, and the others respond with matching efforts. But AI is not a weapon; it is a software tool and not easily made lethal. Creating AI tools is largely a business competition, not two states stockpiling weapons. AI competition involves dozens of private actors guided by market forces. Innovation and production are driven by profit motives. The leading companies involved are not building weapons and some, at least in the US, even assert altruistic motives. The most reliable metrics of success are company revenue and market share, which reflect both performance and the ability to innovate. The same metrics – national income and market share – apply to nations in determining their technological strengths. 
Gauging success in an AI “race” is complicated. There are so many statistics and so little agreement on which are meaningful for strategic advantage that an artful selection can present whatever story one wants. Possible metrics could include deployed military systems using some form of AI, R&D spending, manufacturing capabilities, or business adoption. A review of this data produces mixed results but point to a US lead. The US private sector has twice as many AI researchers, invests almost three times as much as China, and dominates the production of key technologies like semiconductors. Some studies that China may lead in AI startup investment and hopes to close any “gap” by 2030.

The nation that “dominates” AI will not be “.” It is more likely that the nation that is best at creating and accommodating technological change will do better economically than others. Both China and the US have strengths and weaknesses in this. Since AI requires hardware (like GPUs), math, coding skills, and access to data, there is no “chokepoint” where one side can deny AI to the other. A competitor can compensate for lower-performance GPUs by aggregating them or by using software workarounds.
To gain advantage, policies that accelerate research and ease connection to the global innovation system would best serve the United States. Attempting to win the “race” by tripping opponents can actually undercut American leadership by harming the ability to invest and innovate. Changing course in Washington may require a new generation of policymakers who better understand technology and are comfortable with it. This change has already happened in business, where most large companies embrace technology to cut costs and increase revenue, with many exploring how to use AI to “disrupt” their own internal processes to become more competitive.
The concept of an AI arms race is appealing as it simplifies complex issues and provides a handy rhetorical device, but it is unhelpful both as a metric and as a guide for policy. Adoption of AI promises economic benefits, but not necessarily military strength or global influence. Discussions on the effect of AI often start with the technology and leap to the conclusion of increased power without considering the many intermediate steps and difficulties in getting from software to outcomes. Discussions of an AI arms race are often an imperfect retread of nuclear debates. Abandoning the use of terms borrowed from 20 century defense and strategy would lead to better policy. We did not talk about an “internet arms race” 25 years ago even though that technology led to immense change. We should not talk about an AI arms race now.

excerpts:
In 2015, a group of prominent AI and robotics researchers signed an open letter warning of the dangers of autonomous weapons. “The key question for humanity today,” they wrote, “is whether to start a global AI arms race or to prevent it from starting. If any major military power pushes ahead with AI weapon development, a global arms race is virtually inevitable.” Today, many nations are working to apply AI for military advantage, and the term “AI arms race” has become a catchphrase used by both critics and proponents of AI militarization. In 2018, then-Under Secretary of Defense Michael Griffin, calling for the United States to invest more in AI, stated, “There might be an artificial intelligence arms race, but we’re not yet in it.” In a 2020 article, Will Roper, then chief acquisition officer for the U.S. Air Force, warned of the risks of falling behind in a “digital arms race with China.”
The so-called AI arms race has become a common feature in news headlines, but the arms race framing fails to match reality. While nations are clearly competing to develop and adopt AI technology for military use, the character of that competition does not meet the traditional definition of an arms race. Military AI competition nevertheless does pose risks. The widespread adoption of military AI could cause warfare to evolve in a manner that leads to less human control and to warfare becoming faster, more violent, and more challenging in terms of being able to manage escalation and bring a war to an end. Additionally, perceptions of a “race” to field AI systems before competitors do could cause nations to cut corners on testing, leading to the deployment of unsafe AI systems that are at risk of accidents that could cause unintended escalation or destruction. Even if fears of an “AI arms race” are overblown, military AI competition brings real risks to which nations should attend. There are concrete steps nations can take to mitigate some of these dangers.

Being ahead of the curve in adopting AI is likely to lead to significant national advantages. Although AI can increase military capabilities, the more consequential advantages over the long term may come from non-military AI applications across society. Long-term benefits from AI could include increased productivity, improved healthcare outcomes, economic growth, and other indicators of national well-being. Increasing productivity is especially significant because it has a compounding effect on economic growth. Over the long term, technological progress is the main driver of economic growth.
> “The scale of military AI spending, at least at present, is nowhere near large enough to warrant the title of “arms race.””
Of course, AI can also be used for weapons. Militaries around the world are actively working to adopt AI to improve their military capabilities. Yet the militarization of AI does not, at present, meet the traditional definition of an arms race, despite the rhetorical urgency of many national leaders. Michael D. Wallace, in his 1979 article “Arms Races and Escalation,” defined an arms race as “involving simultaneous abnormal rates of growth in the military outlays of two or more nations” resulting from “the competitive pressure of the military itself, and not from domestic forces exogenous to this rivalry.” Wallace further stated that the concept of an arms race only applied “between nations whose foreign and defense policies are heavily interdependent” and who have “roughly comparable” capabilities. AI is being adopted by many countries around the globe. Arguably at least some of the dyads, such as the United States and China, meet Wallace’s definition in terms of being nations with “roughly comparable” capabilities, locked in competition, “whose foreign and defense policies are heavily interdependent.” However, AI fails the arms race test in the critical area of spending.

Arms races result in situations in which two or more countries are locked in spiraling defense spending, grabbing ever-greater shares of national treasure often with little to no net gain in relative advantage over the other. Classic historical examples include the Anglo-German naval arms race prior to World War I and the U.S.-Soviet nuclear arms race during the Cold War. Military AI spending today clearly does not meet these criteria of abnormally large growth rates in defense spending. AI defense spending is difficult to calculate due to the general-purpose nature of AI technology. Unlike ships or ballistic missiles, AI systems cannot be easily counted. Nevertheless, even crude estimates of defense spending show that military AI investments are nowhere near large enough to constitute an arms race. An independent estimate by Bloomberg Government of U.S. defense spending on AI identified $5 billion in AI-related research and development in fiscal year 2020, or roughly 0.7 percent of the Department of Defense’s over $700 billion budget. The scale of military AI spending, at least at present, is nowhere near large enough to warrant the title of “arms race.” (Adding in private sector spending, which constitutes the bulk of AI investment, would lead to larger figures but would further belie the claim of an “arms” race since most private sector AI investment is not in weapons.)
## AI Competition and the Security Dilemma

excerpts:
China’s AI research and development efforts, backed by $200 billion in state investment in AI-related firms over the past decade, reflect a comprehensive approach that spans civilian, commercial, and military domains []. This integrated strategy is narrowing the technological gap between China and the West. Without coordinated, forward-looking action, the U.S. could face significant vulnerabilities in areas such as cyber defense, election security, and automated decision-making systems in critical sectors.
International institutions, including the United Nations Institute for Disarmament Research (UNIDIR) and the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), have called for embedding ethical safeguards and accountability into the development of military AI [, ]. U.S. policymakers should align with these calls, ensuring that AI capabilities are developed in a way that supports both strategic deterrence and humanitarian obligations. In short, national security imperatives demand that AI governance be viewed not as a constraint, but as a strategic asset.
##  Strategic priorities for U.S. AI leadership
To address the scale and complexity of today’s AI challenges, the U.S. must pursue an assertive, multi-pronged strategy to sustain its global leadership.
First, it must increase public investment in platforms like NAIRR to ensure democratic oversight of AI development, counterbalance commercial monopolies, and promote accessibility for academia and startups.
Second, the U.S. must forge stronger AI alliances with the EU, U.K., and Japan to shape interoperable governance norms and promote responsible AI standards globally. These strategic alliances would prevent any one country from dominating global AI influence while also assisting nations in dire need that lag behind in AI development.
Third, the U.S. should develop balanced, evidence-informed frameworks that safeguard national security while encouraging innovation and economic growth.

excerpts: China, the United States (US), and the European Union (EU) have all spoken of a global competition surrounding Artificial Intelligence (AI). There is widespread talk of an ‘AI Arms Race’ (United Nations ; Wired ) as well as a ‘race to regulate’ AI (Smuha ). In a narrower sense, this discourse refers to AI components of autonomous weapons systems (AWS) and similar military AI applications (Maas ). But the ‘arms race’ metaphor is also applied to AI technologies more generally. This discourse frames the major powers of the world as being in a race for technological supremacy, with the ‘winner’ accruing major economic, political and strategic benefits. The emergence of this debate since about 2016 is noteworthy, given that the term AI has existed since 1956 and that the industry has since undergone several boom-and-bust cycles. However, as a series of publications (Asaro ; Dear ; Roff ; Scharre ) has already pointed out, framing AI development as an ‘arms race’ is a mischaracterisation which obfuscates the blurring of economy and security in contemporary great power politics. There are understandable reasons for political actors to ‘weaponise’ or frame innovation dynamics in such terms, such as a desire to preserve technological leadership or maybe even a genuine sense of threat based on perceptions of a technological capability gap (Johnson ). However, this rather indicates the instrumentalisation of the metaphor for political purposes instead of an accurate depiction of competition in the context of AI research and development (R&D). Further, framing AI development in ‘arms race’ terms may induce researchers to prioritise speed over safety and ethics (Armstrong, Bostrom, and Shulman ; Cave and ÓhÉigeartaigh ; Han et al. ).

. At the same time, considering the temporal development of a race, competition implies acceleration and that ‘over time the relative military advantages disappear’ (Asaro , 49). Further, it is pointed out that ‘perceptions of a “race” to field AI systems competitors do could cause nations to ’ (Scharre ; emph. added). In sum, in an innovation race, companies strive for innovation and the expected pay-offs of a technological breakthrough shape the incentives to these companies – the larger the payoff, the fiercer the race. To this end, companies collaborate with outside researchers and other companies to maximise their chances. States support these endeavours through economic policies and research funding. In contrast, in an arms race there is continuous competition and investment, with actors envisioning (relative) advantages and seeing no scenario of possible collaboration (Asaro ). With regard to AI innovation, it is indicated that there are instances of collaboration across technopoles and over time. However, we find that positive-sum scenarios are rare as innovation is envisioned to be radical and thus beneficial to actors’ own positioning through gaining relative advantages. Similar to other digital technology (Baur ), AI innovation takes place in a geopoliticised landscape, in which positive-sum scenarios are rare. There is a mix of competition and collaboration: Platform companies from the US and China dominate this market due to their unprecedented access to data, computing power, capital, and engineering talent (Lee ; Miailhe ). At the same time, the iterative nature of AI R&D over the course of decades as well as cooperation between innovative actors across nations (OECD ) indicates that the race – or rather actors’ perception of it – does not necessitate leading to ever-escalating, accelerating interactions.
cited_documents.title: Arms Race or Innovation Race? Geopolitical AI Development
